IU bounces back from U of L vs. Grand Canyon

Indiana put together one of its best second halves of the season on Saturday night, outscoring Grand Canyon 52-35 in the second half in a 94-66 victory for the Hoosiers.

IU bounces back from U of L vs. Grand Canyon

By Zach Osterman, The Indianapolis Star 8:54 p.m. EST December 13, 2014

Dec 13, 2014; Bloomington, IN, USA; Indiana Hoosiers guard Stanford Robinson (22) drives to the basket with Grand Canyon Antelopes forward Daniel Alexander (12) defending during the first half at Assembly Hall. Mandatory Credit: Pat Lovell-USA TODAY Sports(Photo: Pat Lovell-USA TODAY Sports)

CONNECT 1 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

BLOOMINGTON, Ind. -- There's not much more to learn from games like this.

Indiana (8-2) is now three games away from the start of Big Ten play, two of them against what coach Tom Crean called "household-name" opponents. No. 15 Butler and Georgetown, sandwiched around a home date with New Orleans, make up the rest of the non-conference schedule, and they will test IU seriously.

But the games that end in quiet blowouts like Saturday's 94-66 win over outgunned Grand Canyon have outlived their usefulness.

The Antelopes (4-6) were no match for Indiana in what served as a get-right game after absorbing a 20-point loss to the University of Louisville earlier this week in New York.

Troy Williams served as the poster child. His 14-point, eight-rebound, no-turnover performance was a stark departure from his sloppy night against the Cardinals, when he managed just one rebound, and gave the ball away three times.

"It feels good not to be a turnover machine," Williams joked postgame.

The Antelopes were a good punching bag against which to release Tuesday's frustrations for Indiana in general.

Former NBA star Dan Majerle's team couldn't match the Hoosiers on the glass (and Indiana's hardly among the country's best rebounding teams), and they managed to force their hosts into just four turnovers. That's a single-game low in Crean's IU tenure.

Grand Canyon, despite keeping the deficit within single digits for much of the first half, never had a chance Saturday night.

There's only one more of these games left on Indiana's schedule now, and it's just as well.

Even the mismatches can yield lessons in the non-conference season, up to a point. They help establish rotations and roles, let key newcomers settle in comfortably and generally give a team a sense of its strengths and weaknesses.

We know now that Indiana needs to work on rebounding as a team, Saturday notwithstanding, and that the Hoosiers have to get better stopping the dribble penetration that crippled them in losses to Louisville and Eastern Washington.

"I think that's on everybody's list," said James Blackmon Jr., IU's leading scorer with 18 points Saturday. "Tonight, we had a very good game. We just want to keep getting better."

Crean also fairly pointed out that simply learning to take bad teams seriously is a lesson in itself.

He drew a straight line between Indiana's lackluster second-half performance against Lamar in November, and its upset home loss to Eastern Washington just two nights later.

"There's the household-name games and then there's all the games, and you've got to get (players) to understand how important those are," Crean said. "There's momentum inside the season."

That's a lesson Crean will hope Indiana has learned. It's also one that won't make much difference from here on.

Indiana has the coming week to catch its breath and concentrate on finals. Butler awaits in the fourth-annual Crossroads Classic on Saturday, and then IU returns to New York to face Georgetown a week later.

"It's gonna be a very hard game," Crean said of Butler. "But if our guys look at that any differently than they look at the New Orleans game or beyond, then somewhere down the line, we won't be ready for a Georgetown, or somebody like that."

That New Orleans game wedged in between shouldn't be much of a challenge, given that the Privateers are 2-3 and were picked to finish ninth in the Southland Conference, one spot ahead of Lamar. Those two wins? Over Pensacola Christian and Crowley's Ridge.

The Hoosiers have hardly proven themselves, at least not as the team they want to be a Big Ten contender and NCAA tournament invitee. But they've gotten enough out of the bad games to be done with them now.

There's little of value left to learn from these prearranged blowouts, other than whether Indiana can, as Crean said, keep its wits enough to beat one of the worst teams on the schedule this season.

INDIANA 94, GRAND CANYON 66

GRAND CANYON (4-6) - Jaksic 3-6 0-0 6, Russell 7-16 2-3 16, Braun 3-7 0-0 7, Garrison 1-6 0-0 3, Woolridge 7-12 4-6 18, Juarez 0-0 0-0 0, Majerle 0-2 0-0 0, Jackson 0-2 2-2 2, Davis 1-7 2-2 4, Alexander 2-7 2-2 6, Smith 2-2 0-0 4, Estelle 0-0 0-0 0. Totals 26-67 12-15 66.

INDIANA (8-2) - Williams 5-9 4-6 14, Mosquera-Perea 4-7 3-5 11, Blackmon Jr. 7-14 3-3 18, Johnson 3-6 0-0 7, Ferrell 3-15 0-0 8, Zeisloft 3-7 0-0 9, Hoetzel 2-3 0-0 5, Burton 1-1 0-0 2, Robinson 2-5 4-8 8, Ritchie 0-1 0-0 0, Holt 1-1 4-5 6, Hartman 2-5 0-0 6, Priller 0-1 0-0 0. Totals 33-75 18-27 94.

HalftimeIndiana 42-31. 3-Point GoalsGrand Canyon 2-16 (Braun 1-2, Garrison 1-5, Davis 0-1, Woolridge 0-1, Jaksic 0-1, Jackson 0-1, Majerle 0-2, Alexander 0-3), Indiana 10-30 (Zeisloft 3-7, Hartman 2-4, Ferrell 2-7, Hoetzel 1-2, Johnson 1-3, Blackmon Jr. 1-5, Robinson 0-2). Fouled OutAlexander, Woolridge. ReboundsGrand Canyon 35 (Davis 9), Indiana 52 (Williams 8). AssistsGrand Canyon 8 (Russell, Woolridge 2), Indiana 15 (Blackmon Jr., Ferrell, Zeisloft 3). Total FoulsGrand Canyon 23, Indiana 16. A17,472.
